title: Added tests that ensure correct handling of setting Serial pins to NC
body: These tests ensure that an mbed platform correctly handles having Serial pins set to NC. It tests to ensure that the target can only transmit or only receive (respectively for serial_nc_tx and serial_nc_rx).

title: Change target name not use low cases
body:
Rev.101 mbed library support WIZnet platfrom.  However, we got build error as below by online compiler:

```
Target “WIZWIKI_W7500” is not recognized
```

This is because target name contained low cases (e.g. WIZwiki_W7500).
The target name should be all upper case.

title: Refactor gcc arm exporter templates
body:
All gcc arm exporter templates are changed, but EFM32 ones. They have another internal structure and can be adapted later on.

The main logic is now in the file workspace_tools/export/gcc_arm_common.tmpl
All target platforms now support the same make targets with the same behavior.

Main changes:
- All Cortex M0(+) targets exclude the floating point support for printf and scanf, see https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/compare/mbedmicro:master...chrta:refactor_gcc_arm_exporter_templates?expand=1#diff-8d651adf7eb70cde396310b384cf3e5fR42 and the following line.
- All Cortex M4F-Cores now support setting the float-abi via make parameter.
- The cpu compiler flags are now taken from the toolchain class and used in the templates

This relates to #370

title: USBDevice const correctness issues.
body:
`USBDevice::write[NB]()` have signatures like this:

```
bool write(uint8_t endpoint, uint8_t * buffer, uint32_t size, uint32_t maxSize);
```

`buffer` should be `const uint8_t* buffer`.

This issue is to verify if ksd template is still functional. There has been some reports, some older even ,that KDS export for K64F is not functional.

https://developer.mbed.org/questions/4036/Exporting-to-Kinetis-Design-Studio/?c=18157

We should get the latest version and test K64F, might require update of the template.

title: [STM32F4xx] correction of PWM frequency calculation
body:
All STM32F4xx targets with a clock frequency larger than 100MHz (F405, F407, F429, F446), have two different maximal timer frequencies: SYSCLK and SYSCLK/2. The pwm frequency calculation was based only on SYSCLK. For Nucleo targets this was OK but for some Discovery and some other targets the pwm frequency was partly wrong, depending on the used timer.

This PR reads out the specific timer clock configuration and calculates the correct pwm frequency.

title: [DISCO_F334C8] Add uVision and IAR exporters
[utils.py] Making some functions more generic
body:
This pull request should make some functions more generic.

There was a an issue with `find_cmd_abspath` in Windows where no lookup for files with extensions was made. [This was fixed.](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/pull/1114) The problem is that the fix didn't take into consideration some other issues. I list below the main such issues:
1. Only `.exe` files are looked up on Windows (no .bat scripts for example)
2. Returned `abspath` in `find_cmd_abspath` is missing the extension!
3. The same path separator ('/') was used for all OSes. (bug from before)
4. Some checking and normalization (ie. trailing `"` in PATH variable).

After the fixes, `find_cmd_abspath` should work for any platform in a generic way. I have tested both `find_cmd_abspath` and `is_valid_cmd` on Linux and Windows after the changes.

title: Update nRF51822 softdevice to s130 in GCC export sciprt
body: The main source code has removed the s110 softdevice in favour of s130. This fixes the GCC ARM export template.

Marco

title: Sample Implementation of Revised PinMode Definition For KL25Z
body:
**DO NOT MERGE**

The rest of the platforms will have to be updated too before this could be merged.

This is a sample implementation for the KL25Z of the changes I proposed in this issue: https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/1064

I've made a few changes. I've moved the mentioned function `gpio_mode_supported` in the issue to the pinmap api as `int pin_supports_mode(PinName pin, PinMode mode);`. You can also configure an input pin to an unsupported mode, as all possible PinModes are now defined for all platforms. Right now it will simply ignore the request and leave the pin unchanged. However, you can proactively check if the pin supports a given PinMode by calling `pin_supports_mode`.

I've tested this with the KL25Z using the automated test suite and it passes all tests. I've also used a logic analyzer and I can see the "PullUp" and "PullNone" options changing the idle level of the pin.

I'd like to hear feedback on this change. How could this be better organized? Should the C++ API be changed as well to return information on (un)supported PinModes?

title: [RTOS] Added stack checking methods to Thread
body: Added stack checking methods to the Thread class for Cortex-M targets. The stack memory size, currently free stack memory, and currently used stack memory are calculated using the TCB. The maximum stack memory usage is determined by filling the stack with a magic word, and finding the high water mark.

title: Tools: Interoperability test suite: Added simple interface chip tests / checks
body:
# Description

This new functionality allows users to perform simple interface chip tests / checks in order to determine if mbed device is in-line with various levels of mbed 2.0 / mbed-enabled compatibility.
## Limitations
- This feature only works with `mbed-ls` module and `--auto` switch. If `mbed-ls` is installed users can use new option `--oper` to force interoperability tests on all connected devices.
- Interoperability test results can be imported only to JUnit. No HTML, JSON exporters yet. Feel free to add them.
# New command line option --oper

New command line switch `--oper=SCOPE` comes with few flavors:
- `basic` - check for basic compatibility.
- `mbed-enabled` - set of checks for mbed-enabled standard compatibility.
  Note: mbed-enabled standard is being developed now and requirements are not set in stone so 
- `pedantic` - set of detailed checks. Note: it is not yet implemented.
- `all` - Run all checks / tests.

Add `--report-junit=FILE_NAME` to `--auto --oper=SCOPE` to export results to JUnit format output file.

To see all available interoperability test suite options use:

```
$ singletest.py --help
Usage: singletest.py [options]

This script allows you to run mbed defined test cases for particular MCU(s)
and corresponding toolchain(s).

Options:
.
.
.
  --auto                Use mbed-ls module to detect all connected mbed
                        devices
  --tc=TOOLCHAINS_FILTER
                        Toolchain filter for --auto option. Use toolchains
                        names separated by comma, 'default' or 'all' to select
                        toolchains
  --oper=OPERABILITY_CHECKS
                        Perform interoperability tests between host and
                        connected mbed devices. Available test scopes are:
                        'mbed-enabled','all','basic'
.
.
.
```
## Examples:

New interoperability test suite is called by adding `--oper` switch to `singletest.py --auto` command:

```
$ singletest.py --auto --oper=basic
```

or

```
$ singletest.py --auto --oper=mbed-enabled
```

or

```
$ singletest.py --auto --oper=all
```
## Examples:

FRDM-K64F interoperability `basic` test suite portfolio (tests/checks examples):

```
$ singletest.py --auto --oper=basic
MBEDLS: Detecting connected mbed-enabled devices...
MBEDLS: Detected K64F, port: COM61, mounted: I:
MBEDLS: Detected K64F, port: COM61, mounted: I:
Running interoperability test suite, scope 'basic'
+----------+----------------------+--------+-------+------------------------------------------------+
| Platform | Test Case            | Result | Scope | Description                                    |
+----------+----------------------+--------+-------+------------------------------------------------+
| K64F     | FILE_EXIST(MBED.HTM) | PASS   | basic | File 'I:mbed.htm' exists                       |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID            | PASS   | basic | TargetID '02400203D94B0E7724B7F3CF' found      |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_DECODE     | PASS   | basic | TargetID '0240' decoded as 'K64F'              |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_MATCH      | PASS   | basic | TargetID (USBID) and TargetID (mbed.htm) match |
+----------+----------------------+--------+-------+------------------------------------------------+
```

FRDM-K64F interoperability `mbed-enabled` test suite portfolio (tests/checks examples):

```
$ singletest.py --auto --oper=mbed-enabled
MBEDLS: Detecting connected mbed-enabled devices...
MBEDLS: Detected K64F, port: COM61, mounted: I:
MBEDLS: Detected K64F, port: COM61, mounted: I:
Running interoperability test suite, scope 'mbed-enabled'
+----------+-------------------------+--------+--------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Platform | Test Case               | Result | Scope        | Description                                                       |
+----------+-------------------------+--------+--------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------+
| K64F     | FILE_EXIST(DETAILS.TXT) | ERROR  | mbed-enabled | File 'I:DETAILS.TXT' not found                                    |
| K64F     | FILE_EXIST(MBED.HTM)    | PASS   | basic        | File 'I:mbed.htm' exists                                          |
| K64F     | FILE_EXIST(MBED.HTM)    | PASS   | mbed-enabled | File 'I:mbed.htm' exists                                          |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID               | PASS   | basic        | TargetID '02400203D94B0E7724B7F3CF' found                         |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_DECODE        | PASS   | basic        | TargetID '0240' decoded as 'K64F'                                 |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_LEN           | PASS   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) '02400203D94B0E7724B7F3CF' is 24 chars long      |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_LEN           | PASS   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) '02400203D94B0E7724B7F3CF' is 24 chars long   |
| K64F     | TARGET_ID_MATCH         | PASS   | basic        | TargetID (USBID) and TargetID (mbed.htm) match                    |
| K64F     | FILE_EXIST(FAIL.TXT)    | INFO   | mbed-enabled | File 'I:FAIL.TXT' not found                                       |
| K64F     | FW_HASH_SEC             | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) Hash of secret is 'D94B0E7724B7F3CF'             |
| K64F     | FW_HASH_SEC             | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) Hash of secret is 'D94B0E7724B7F3CF'          |
| K64F     | FW_PLAT_CODE            | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) Platform Code is '40'                            |
| K64F     | FW_PLAT_CODE            | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) Platform Code is '40'                         |
| K64F     | FW_VEN_CODE             | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) Vendor Code is '02'                              |
| K64F     | FW_VEN_CODE             | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) Vendor Code is '02'                           |
| K64F     | FW_VER                  | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) Firmware Version is '0203'                       |
| K64F     | FW_VER                  | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) Firmware Version is '0203'                    |
| K64F     | FW_VER_STR              | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (USBID) Version String is 0240.0203.D94B0E7724B7F3CF     |
| K64F     | FW_VER_STR              | INFO   | mbed-enabled | TargetId (mbed.htm) Version String is 0240.0203.D94B0E7724B7F3CF  |
+----------+-------------------------+--------+--------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------+
```

title: New mbed library features implementation
body:
Decided to post this again: This is not a real issue, but a question + a complaint (which you could also call an issue).

To start with: What is mbed HQs plan with the newly introduced APIs? For which targets are you going to implement the async options. What is the time scale for that? What about the other boards? And maybe add on the site an automatically generated table to list which boards support which features.

Then the complaint: Was it ever considered to discuss the new API stuff with the people contributing to mbed? Maybe they have ideas too... I am sure the guys at Silicon Labs had their say, but what about everyone else? Both the hobbyists and developers of other companies? 

Also maybe some documentation would be useful. Random example:  https://developer.mbed.org/users/mbed_official/code/mbed-src/file/1abac31e188e/hal/dma_api.h. I am sure I can figure out what the functions are supposed to do, but it is all a bit cryptic now.

Reading the ADC in the main loop after the call to deepsleep, returns 0.0000. This is not correct, but if I use sleep the value is correct.

title: Introduction of new platform LPC2460 MCU
body:
I added support of new target platform LPC2460 (ARM7TDMI-S based 32-bit RISC Microcontroller with Thumb extensions, 98KB RAM, CPU clock up to 72 MHz)

Only GCC ARM toolchain is supported.
This Pull Request contains two parts:
1. CMSIS-HAL for LPC2460 with tested drivers for  Digital I/O and IRQ, PWM, I2C, SPI, UART, ADC/DAC,  RTC. And not tested drivers for CAN, Ethernet, USB.
2. RTX support for ARM7TMI-S processors and LPC2560 in particular.

Solution has been tested on some proprietary board (not on an evaluation board).

title: ERROR: run_cmd in build.py
body:
I got following error in build.py, even I didn't change my private_settings.py and build toolchain directory.

```
C:\Users\toywat01\Documents\GitHub\mbed>workspace_tools\build.py -m LPC1768 -t ARM -c
Building library CMSIS (LPC1768, ARM)
Copy: core_ca9.h
Copy: core_caFunc.h
Copy: core_caInstr.h
Copy: core_ca_mmu.h
Copy: core_cm0.h
Copy: core_cm0plus.h
Copy: core_cm3.h
Copy: core_cm4.h
Copy: core_cm4_simd.h
Copy: core_cmFunc.h
Copy: core_cmInstr.h
Copy: cmsis.h
Copy: cmsis_nvic.h
Copy: LPC17xx.h
Copy: system_LPC17xx.h
Copy: LPC1768.sct
ERROR: run_cmd: Command 'C:\Keil\ARM\armcc\bin\armcc' can't be found
```

I found that it came up by change of the utils.py script here.  To workaround of this, comment out the single line below.

https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/workspace_tools/utils.py#L36

This modification had been done by:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/commit/ecc0e324409740bfd8bdfda07eb48eb261e6da49
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/commit/62a10cee03515d8f0ece843a889d036fd02b860e

@Pithikos, how did you test this script?

I am using Windows 7 and python 2.7.9.

title: Offline compilation using workspace_tools
body:
1.  Exported files from the online IDE and `workspace_tools\project.py` have very different `Makefile`, specifically `SYS_OBJECTS`, `INCLUDE_PATHS` and `LIBRARY_PATHS` and `CC_FLAGS`. I did not test the exports projects as my local setup is not yet complete. **What is the reason for two different type of Makefile?** For offline compilation, the user should have the complete mbed file directory such that he/she could get the latest update easily and multiple projects can share the same source code.
2.  I am able to test those _test programs_ using `workspace_tools\make.py`. I noticed that the script is able to detect and compile newly updated files - a feature provided by `make`. However there is no make in my environment. From my initial browsing through the code, it does not use `Makefile`. **How can I use any of the scripts in `workspace\` to compile a non-test programs?**

title: Minor spelling correction
body: Corrected minor spelling mistakes and sentences in BUILDING.md.

title: [RZ_A1H]Fix bugs of I2C and Update a header file of Video driver.
body:
Hi,

We fixed bugs of I2C and update a header file of Video driver.

I2C
Bugs are as below.
- In I2C, modify the time-out of Nack is slow problem.
- In I2C, modify Write function and Read function does not work correctly with split run.

Header file
Update the header file for the Video driver support.

Regards,
Hamanaka

title: Added support to Thread::signal_wait_or on CORTEX_M devices
[Silicon Labs] Update exporter for Simplicity Studio
body:
- Remove references to auto-included libraries
- Update Happy Gecko STK ID
- Apply workaround for known linker input ordering issue

title: Fix bug with CAN loopback implementation on LPC11c14
body: While compiling and running the updated MBed repository code for the LPC11c14, I discovered that the can_api.c file in the \LPC11XX_11CXX\LPC11CXX target folder was not building correctly. It appears that there is a spurious "CANCNTL_LBACK" which should actually be "CANTEST_LBACK." I have modified the file to mirror the contents of the can_api.c file in the LPC15XX target folder and it appears to work now.

title: gmtime parses time_t incorrectly
body:
The gmtime function seems to return incorrect values for hour, minutes and seconds in the tm struct.

I compared mbed's gmtime with the implementation in the newlib library (http://sourceware.org/newlib/);  newlib works as expected.

Sample program here: 
https://developer.mbed.org/users/bjblazkowicz/code/gmtime_test/file/53c251120904/main.cpp

title: [MAX32600MBED,MAXWSNENV] addressed low-power ticker corner cases
body: Fixed some corner case issues with waking up from the low-power ticker.

title: STM32F4: HSE timeout increased from 0.5s to 5s, needs 10seconds to fallback to HSI
body:
Hi,
i saw mbed-src have been upgraded to CubeF4 drivers v1.5, which increases HSE timeout from 500 to 5000 ms.
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/cmsis/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/TARGET_NUCLEO_F401RE/stm32f4xx_hal_conf.h#L104
I don't know if there have been issues with 500ms timeout (afaik issues were about LSE on Nucleo boards with not correct capacitors), anyway now it takes 10 seconds to fallback to HSI (HSEwBypass->HSEwoBypass->HSI).

title: Fixes for premature error checking
body:
Some issues fixed:
1. Added command validation before running a command. The validation assures that the command resolves to an executable file. Descriptive feedback is printed on error.
2. Falsely giving errors for modules that have not been extracted from their .egg. These modules can be imported but false errors were given that they are not installed on the system.

Feedback example:

```
manos@box:~/tmp/mbed/workspace_tools$ python -B build.py -m LPC1768 -t uARM
..
ERROR: run_cmd: Command 'C:/Program Files/ARM/armcc_4.1_791/bin/armcc' can't be found
```

title: Tools: Added support for testing of multiple targets of the same type (board type)
body:
# Description

It was impossible to run test using `singletest.py` on more than 1 device of the same type (e.g. two Freedom K64F boards).
Before this change test suite (`singletest.py`) would only run tests for one board per type connected skipping (ignoring) other boards. 

**Note**:
- `mbed-ls` was modified to generate extra unique names (human friendly format) for each connected mbed device. This name is used by `singletest.py` and can be used by other applications to drive automation with mbedls and mbed devices.

**Example:**
Two NUCLEO_L152RE boards connected to host computer, both with unique TargetId and assigned readable `platform_name_unique`.

```
$ mbedls
+---------------------+----------------------------+-------------------+-------------------+----------------------------------------+
|platform_name        |platform_name_unique        |mount_point        |serial_port        |target_id                               |
+---------------------+----------------------------+-------------------+-------------------+----------------------------------------+
|K64F                 |K64F[0]                     |I:                 |COM61              |02400203D94B0E7724B7F3CF                |
|LPC1768              |LPC1768[0]                  |E:                 |COM77              |101000000000000000000002F7F18695        |
|NUCLEO_L152RE        |NUCLEO_L152RE[0]            |F:                 |COM113             |07100200656A9A955A0F0CB8                |
|NUCLEO_L152RE        |NUCLEO_L152RE[1]            |G:                 |COM114             |0710020082667D99BD03EBB4                |
+---------------------+----------------------------+-------------------+-------------------+----------------------------------------+
```
## MUTs configuration for singletest.py

You can also execute tests from configuration files: `singletest.py -i test_spec.json -M muts_all.json`. In that case, if you want to for example run tests on multiple devices of the same type you can just specify them in MUTs file and add optional `mcu_unique` to distinguish test results between boards.

**Example**:
Configuring MUTs to run tests for two `NUCLEO_L152RE` boards:

```
...
    "13" : {"mcu" : "NUCLEO_L152RE",
            "port" : "COM114",
            "disk" : "G:\\"},

    "14" : {"mcu" : "NUCLEO_L152RE",
            "port" : "COM113",
            "disk" : "F:\\"},
...
```

or with extra `mcu_unique` name to differentiate tests:

```
...
    "13" : {"mcu" : "NUCLEO_L152RE",
            "mcu_unique" : "NUCLEO_L152RE[1]",
            "port" : "COM114",
            "disk" : "G:\\"},

    "131" : {"mcu" : "NUCLEO_L152RE",
            "mcu_unique" : "NUCLEO_L152RE[0]",
            "port" : "COM113",
            "disk" : "F:\\"},
...
```

test results will be respectively:

```
$ singletest.py -i test_spec.json -M muts_all.json -n DTCT_1
Building library CMSIS (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
Building library MBED (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
Building project DETECT (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
TargetTest::NUCLEO_L152RE::uARM::DTCT_1::Simple detect test [OK] in 0.48 of 10 sec
TargetTest::NUCLEO_L152RE::uARM::DTCT_1::Simple detect test [OK] in 0.51 of 10 sec
Test summary:
+--------+---------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| Result | Target        | Toolchain | Test ID | Test Description   | Elapsed Time (sec) | Timeout (sec) | Loops |
+--------+---------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| OK     | NUCLEO_L152RE | uARM      | DTCT_1  | Simple detect test |        0.48        |       10      |  1/1  |
| OK     | NUCLEO_L152RE | uARM      | DTCT_1  | Simple detect test |        0.51        |       10      |  1/1  |
+--------+---------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
Result: 2 OK

Completed in 7.80 sec

Build successes:
  * uARM::NUCLEO_L152RE
```

and

```
$ singletest.py -i test_spec.json -M muts_all.json -n DTCT_1
Building library CMSIS (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
Building library MBED (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
Building project DETECT (NUCLEO_L152RE, uARM)
TargetTest::NUCLEO_L152RE[0]::uARM::DTCT_1::Simple detect test [OK] in 0.49 of 10 sec
TargetTest::NUCLEO_L152RE[1]::uARM::DTCT_1::Simple detect test [OK] in 0.51 of 10 sec
Test summary:
+--------+------------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| Result | Target           | Toolchain | Test ID | Test Description   | Elapsed Time (sec) | Timeout (sec) | Loops |
+--------+------------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| OK     | NUCLEO_L152RE[0] | uARM      | DTCT_1  | Simple detect test |        0.49        |       10      |  1/1  |
| OK     | NUCLEO_L152RE[1] | uARM      | DTCT_1  | Simple detect test |        0.51        |       10      |  1/1  |
+--------+------------------+-----------+---------+--------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
Result: 2 OK

Completed in 7.84 sec

Build successes:
  * uARM::NUCLEO_L152RE
```
# Testing

Tested with multiple execution patterns: 
- `singletest.py -i test_spec.json -M muts_all.json -n DTCT_1`
- `singletest.py --auto --parallel --report-junit pr_ju.xml --report-build pr_bld.html --report-html pr_html.html`
- `singletest.py --auto  --tc IAR`

title: [MAX32600MBED,MAXWSNENV] Added low-power ticker.
body: The adding of the low-power ticker API in #1079 caused build failures in the MAX32600MBED and MAXWSNENV platforms. This commit fixes these failures by implementing the low-power ticker for these platforms.

title: [Silicon Labs] Add the no-rtti C++ compilation flag required for linking libmbed.
[Silicon Labs] Set the default status for an input pin to PullUp instead of PullDown
body: ... in order to better match the Starter Kit pushbutton design, and align with the expectations of mbed.

title: Updated Thread.cpp|.h to support signal clear
Pullup/pulldown wrong configuration in STM32F1 mcu
body: As commented in [mbed issue](https://developer.mbed.org/users/mbed_official/code/mbed-src/issues/14). Exists a bug on InterruptIn pullup/pulldown configuration for STM32F1 mcu. This pull request solves it.

title: [HAL][KSDK] Fix issue with KSDK SPI timing
body:
Depending on the format by default the Freescale SPI peripheral does not
give proper delay between SPI transfers. So code has been added which
sets half a period delay between SPI transfers.

See the following picture:
http://static.tweakers.net/ext/f/gAoTfuAGPXuMgtqbCm34UOJ9/full.png

This is related to https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/840 (you can see the same clock issue in the pic there). This issue: https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/968 does not seem to be solved by this, in mode 3 the MOSI line goes up stil way too soon.

title: Tools: bugfix: singletes.py was not reporting test case build failure
body:
# Description
1. singletest.py was not reporting in summary table or other reports test case build failure. Thi issue was observed in team's internal CI server.
2. Added new error code to sibgletst.py called `BUILD_FAILURE` - used when test case build fails.
3. Added new summary: Build successful, skipped and failed - the same summary as in build.py.

Example of test case build failure:

```
.
.
Building project DETECT (K64F, ARM)
Compile: main.cpp
[Error] main.cpp@4:  #35: #error directive: Error added for test
[23:19:24] Error: There were errors while building project DTCT_1
.
.
```

Example of fixed behavior where singletest.py is fetching information about failed test case build and passing to results tables (also JUnit and HTML reports).
In below example test DICT_1 is failing to build and summary is enriched with BUILD_FAILURE

```
$ singletest.py --auto -j 8 -n DTCT_1,RTOS_1 --report-html hr.html
MBEDLS: Detecting connected mbed-enabled devices...
MBEDLS: Detected K64F, port: COM61, mounted: I:
Building library CMSIS (K64F, ARM)
Building library MBED (K64F, ARM)
Building library RTOS (K64F, ARM)
Building library RTX (K64F, ARM)
Building project DETECT (K64F, ARM)
Compile: main.cpp
[Error] main.cpp@4:  #35: #error directive: Error added for test
[23:19:24] Error: There were errors while building project DTCT_1
Building project BASIC (K64F, ARM)
TargetTest::K64F::ARM::RTOS_1::Basic thread [OK] in 11.33 of 15 sec
Test summary:
+--------------+--------+-----------+---------+------------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| Result       | Target | Toolchain | Test ID | Test Description       | Elapsed Time (sec) | Timeout (sec) | Loops |
+--------------+--------+-----------+---------+------------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
| BUILD_FAILED | K64F   | ARM       | DTCT_1  | Toolchain build failed |         0          |       0       |   -   |
| OK           | K64F   | ARM       | RTOS_1  | Basic thread           |       11.33        |       15      |  1/1  |
+--------------+--------+-----------+---------+------------------------+--------------------+---------------+-------+
Result: 1 BUILD_FAILED / 1 OK

Completed in 20.83 sec

Build successes:
  * ARM::K64F

Build failures:
  * ARM::K64F::DTCT_1
```

Tools - check for installed modules using imp is broken (python 2.7.6/9)
body:
I am not able to run singletest.py as there's an error reported.  The script calles check_required_modules:

```
def check_required_modules(required_modules, verbose=True):
    """ Function checks for Python modules which should be "importable" (installed)
        before test suite can be used.
        @return returns True if all modules are installed already
    """
    import imp
    all_modules_found = True
    not_installed_modules = []
    for module_name in required_modules:
        try:
            imp.find_module(module_name)
        except ImportError as e:
            all_modules_found = False
            not_installed_modules.append(module_name)
            if verbose:
                print "Error: %s"% e
    if verbose:
        if not all_modules_found:
            print "Warning: Mod
```

Is imp is broken? as I have installed both modules. A quick test:

```
λ python
Python 2.7.9 (default, Dec 10 2014, 12:28:03) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import serial
>>> import imp
>>> imp.find_module('serial')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: No module named serial
```

title: Stm32cubef4 update
body:
Update of STM32CubeF4 v1.2 to current version 1.5
- Update of all F4 specific files
- Update of all files in target specific folders to new STM32CubeF4 version
- Adaption of gpio_api to new hal version: register to set/clear a pin is now a single 32bit register (the only api change in new STM32CubeF4 version)

singletest of NUCLEO_F411, NUCLEO_F401, DISCO_F407, DISCO_F429 and ARCH MAX (incl. digital_loop), compiling the other targets is OK
